metadata.title: Texas Security Control Standards Catalog Profile

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: Confidential information shall be accessible only to authorized users. An information file or record containing any confidential information shall be identified, documented, and protected in its entirety. Information resources assigned from or shared between one state agency to another or from or between a state agency to a contractor or other third party shall be protected in accordance with the conditions imposed by the providing state agency at a minimum.

part.name: item
part.p: Access to state information resources shall be appropriately managed.

part.name: item
part.p: Each user of information resources shall be assigned a unique identifier except for situations where risk analysis demonstrates no need for individual accountability of users. User identification shall be authenticated before the information resources system may grant that user access.

part.name: item
part.p: As technology permits, state agencies should enforce account lockouts after, at minimum, 10 failed attempts. This threshold may be lowered for Moderate or High risk systems.

part.name: item
part.p: Accounts locked out due to multiple incorrect logon attempts should stay locked out for a minimum of 15 minutes. Accounts for Moderate or High risk systems should remain locked until reset by an administrator.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: System identification/logon banners shall have warning statements that include the following topics: (a) Unauthorized use is prohibited; (b) Usage may be subject to security testing and monitoring; (c) Misuse is subject to criminal prosecution; and (d) Users have no expectation of privacy except as otherwise provided by applicable privacy laws.

part.name: item
part.p: a. State agencies shall establish the requirements and security restrictions for installing or providing access to the state agency's information resources systems. The wireless policy shall address the following topic areas:

part.name: item
part.p: Wireless Local Area Networks. Ensure that Service Set Identifiers (SSID) values are changed from the manufacturer default setting. Some networks should not include organizational or location information in the SSID.

part.name: item
part.p: Transmitting and Encrypting Information. Types of information that may be transmitted via wireless networks and devices with or without encryption including mission critical information or sensitive personal information.

State agencies shall not transmit confidential information via a wireless connection to or from a portable computing device unless encryption methods, such as a Virtual Private Network (VPN), Wi-Fi Protected Access, or other secure encryption protocols that meet appropriate protection or certification standards as detailed within this Security Control Standards Catalog, are used to protect the information.

part.name: item
part.p: Installation or Use of Wireless Personal Area Networks. Prohibit and periodically monitor any unauthorized installation or use of Wireless Personal Area Networks on state agency IT systems by individuals without the approval of the state agency information resources manager.

part.name: item
part.p: Information resources systems shall provide the means whereby authorized personnel have the ability to audit and establish individual accountability for any action that can potentially cause access to, generation or modification of, or affect the release of confidential information.

part.name: item
part.p: Appropriate audit trails shall be maintained to provide accountability for updates to mission critical information, hardware and software, and for all changes to automated security or access rules.

part.name: item
part.p: Based upon a state agencyโs assessment of the risk, the state agency shall maintain a sufficiently complete history of transactions to permit an audit of the information resources system by logging and tracing the activities of individuals through the system.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: A review of the agency's information security program for compliance with these standards will be performed at least biennially, based on business risk management decisions, by individual(s) independent of the information security program and designated by the agency head or his or her designated representative(s).

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: Texas Government Code ยง 2054.516(a)(2) requires each state agency implementing an Internet website or mobile application that processes any sensitive personal or personally identifiable information or confidential information to subject the website or application to a vulnerability and penetration test and address any vulnerability identified in the test.

part.name: item
part.p: All security-related information resources changes shall be approved by the information owner through a change control process.

part.name: item
part.p: Approval shall occur prior to implementation by the state agency or independent contractors.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: State agencies shall maintain written Continuity of Operations Plans in compliance with Texas Labor Code ยง 412.054 that address information resources so that the effects of a disaster will be minimized and the state agency will be able either to maintain or quickly resume mission-critical functions.

part.name: item
part.p: The plan shall be distributed to key personnel and a copy stored offsite. Elements of the plan for information resources shall include:

part.name: item
part.p: Business Impact Analysis to systematically assess the potential impacts of a loss of business functionality due to an interruption of computing and/or infrastructure support services resulting from various events or incidents. The analysis shall identify the following elements:

part.name: item
part.p: Mission-Critical Information Resources (specific system resources required to perform critical functions) to include:

part.name: item
part.p: Internal and external points of contact for personnel that provide or receive data or support interconnected systems.

part.name: item
part.p: Supporting infrastructure such as electric power, telecommunications connections, and environmental controls.

part.name: item
part.p: Disruption impacts and allowable outage times to include:

part.name: item
part.p: Effects of an outage over time to assess the maximum allowable time that a resource may be denied before it prevents or inhibits the performance of an essential function.

part.name: item
part.p: Effects of an outage across related resources and dependent systems to assess cascading effects on associated systems or processes.

part.name: item
part.p: Recovery priorities that consider geographic areas, accessibility, security, environment, and cost and may include a combination of:

part.name: item
part.p: Preventive controls and processes such as backup power, excess capacity, environmental sensors and alarms.

part.name: item
part.p: Recovery techniques and technologies such as backup methodologies, alternate sites, software and hardware equipment replacement, implementation roles and responsibilities.

part.name: item
part.p: Risk Assessment to weigh the cost of implementing preventative measures against the risk of loss from not taking action.

part.name: item
part.p: Implementation, testing, and maintenance management program addressing the initial and ongoing testing and maintenance activities of the plan.

part.name: item
part.p: Disaster Recovery Plan--Each state agency shall maintain a written disaster recovery plan for major or catastrophic events that deny access to information resources for an extended period. Information learned from tests conducted since the plan was last updated will be used in updating the disaster recovery plan. The disaster recovery plan will:

part.name: item
part.p: Contain measures which address the impact and magnitude of loss or harm that will result from an interruption;

part.name: item
part.p: Identify recovery resources and a source for each;

part.name: item
part.p: Contain step-by-step implementation instructions;

part.name: item
part.p: Include provisions for annual testing.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: Each state agency's written disaster recovery plan will include provisions for annual testing.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: Mission-critical information shall be backed up on a scheduled basis and stored off site in a secure, environmentally safe, locked facility accessible only to authorized state agency representatives.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: Each user of information resources shall be assigned a unique identifier except for situations where risk analysis demonstrates no need for individual accountability of users. User identification shall be authenticated before the information resources system may grant that user access.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: A userโs access authorization shall be appropriately modified or removed when the userโs employment or job responsibilities within the state agency change.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: State agencies shall assess the significance of a security incident based upon the business impact on the affected resources and the current and potential technical effect of the incident, e.g., loss of revenue, productivity, access to services, reputation, unauthorized disclosure of confidential information, or propagation to other networks.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: The state agency trains personnel in their incident response roles and responsibilities with respect to the information system and provides refresher training at least annually.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: Reporting of security incidents and the investigation and restoration of operations following a security incident assessed to involve suspected criminal activity shall comply with 1 Texas Administrative Code ยง 202.23(b), 202.73(b).

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: The state agency provides an incident response support resource that offers advice and assistance to users of the information system for the handling and reporting of security incidents. The support resource is an integral part of the agencyโs incident response capability.

part.name: item
part.p: Prior to the sale or transfer of data processing equipment, to other than another Texas state agency or agent of the state, state agencies shall assess whether to remove data from any associated storage device.

part.name: item
part.p: Electronic state records shall be destroyed in accordance with Texas Government Code ยง 441.185 and in compliance with the state agencyโs records retention schedule. If the record retention period applicable for an electronic state record has not expired at the time the record is removed from data process equipment, the state agency shall retain a hard copy or other electronic copy of the record for the required retention period.

part.name: item
part.p: If it is possible that restricted personal information, confidential information, mission critical information, intellectual property, or licensed software is contained on the storage device, the storage device should be sanitized or the storage device should be removed and destroyed. Additional information on sanitization tools and methods of destruction (that comply with the Department of Defense 5220.22-M standard) are provided in the โSale or Transfer of Computers and Softwareโ guidelines available at https://dir.texas.gov/resource-library-item/sale-or-transfer-computers-and-software.

part.name: item
part.p: State agencies shall keep a record/form (electronic or hard copy) documenting the removal and completion of the process with the following information:

part.name: item
part.p: date;

part.name: item
part.p: description of the item(s) and serial number(s);

part.name: item
part.p: inventory number(s);

part.name: item
part.p: the process and sanitization tools used to remove the data or method of destruction; and

part.name: item
part.p: the name and address of the organization the equipment was transferred to.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: Information resources shall be protected from environmental hazards. Designated employees shall be trained to monitor environmental control procedures and equipment and shall be trained in desired response in case of emergencies or equipment problems.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: The state agency information security officer reports annually on state agency information security program in compliance with 1 Texas Administrative Code ยงยง 202.23(a), 202.73(a).

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: The Information Security Officer is charged with the responsibilities enumerated at Texas Government Code ยง 2054.136 and 1 Texas Administrative Code ยง 202.21, 202.71.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: All authorized users (including, but not limited to, state agency personnel, temporary employees, and employees of independent contractors) of the state agencyโs information resources shall formally acknowledge that they will comply with the security policies and procedures of the state agency or they shall not be granted access to information resources. The state agency head or their designated representative will determine the method of acknowledgement and how often this acknowledgement must be reexecuted by the user to maintain access to state agency information resources.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: State agencies are responsible for identifying and defining all information classification categories except the Confidential Information category, as defined by 1 Texas Administrative Code Chapter 202, Subchapter A, and establishing the appropriate controls for each.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: The state agency shall perform and document risk assessments and make and document risk management decisions in compliance with 1 Texas Administrative Code ยงยง 202.25, 202.75, 202.27, 202.77. A state agencyโs security risk management plan may be excepted from disclosure under Texas Government Code ยง 2054.077(c) or Texas Government Code ยง 552.139

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: The state agency scans for vulnerabilities in the information system at least annually or when significant new vulnerabilities potentially affecting the system are identified and reported.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: A state agency shall include information security, security testing, and audit controls in all phases of the system development lifecycle or acquisition process.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: The information owner shall approve all security-related information resources changes through a change control process. Approval shall occur prior to implementation by the state agency or independent contractors.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: Confidential information that is transmitted over a public network (e.g., the Internet) must be encrypted with, at minimum, a 128-bit encryption algorithm. A state agency may also choose to implement encryption for other data classifications.

part.name: item
part.p: Encryption requirements for information storage devices and data transmissions, as well as specific requirements for portable devices, removable media, and encryption key standards and management shall be based on documented state agency risk management decisions.

part.name: item
part.p: Confidential information that is transmitted over a public network (e.g., the Internet) must be encrypted as described by SC-8.

part.name: item
part.p: Confidential information stored in a public location that is directly accessible without compensating controls in place (e.g., FTP without access control) must be encrypted.

part.name: item
part.p: Storing confidential information on portable devices is discouraged. Confidential information must be encrypted if copied to or stored on a portable computing device, removable media, or a non-state agency-owned computing device.

part.name: item
part.p: The minimum algorithm strength for protecting confidential information is a 128-bit encryption algorithm, subject to state agency risk management decisions justified and documented in accordance with 1 Texas Administrative Code ยงยง 202.21(c), 202.71(c), 202.25, 202.75.

part.name: item
part.p: A state organization may also choose to implement additional protections, which may include encryption, for other data classifications.

part.name: tx_implementation
part.p: The state agency identifies, reports, and corrects information system flaws.

part.name: item
part.p: Each state agency head or their designated representative and information security officer shall establish a security strategy that includes perimeter protection.

part.name: item
part.p: The department will provide security information management services to include external network monitoring, scanning, and alerting for state agencies that utilize State information resources as specified in Texas Government Code Chapters 2054 and 2059. Perimeter security controls may include some or all of the following components: Demilitarized Zone (DMZ), firewall, intrusion detection or prevention system, or router.
